column4: I set up a cron tab in root (sudo crontab -e) as the following 5 * * * root rm -rf /home/myUsername/.local/share/Trash. Any help?
You are missing a field
What field? 0.o
Ah, yes, you are mixing crontab -e with /etc/crontab's syntax
But there are 5 time fields in both. /etc/crontab has another (sixth) field, a username.
But sudo didn't work
What do you need sudo for?
I couldn't get it to work, so I assumed I need it?
Such assumptions will get you in trouble later. The problem is, cron expects five fields to describe which times the command should run, you only provided four, so it has no idea what to do.
man 5 crontab
Aren't these the five fields for time: 0 5 * * *
Yes. Now it says to run it every day at 5 o'clock in the morning.
Yes, so what's the problem? I had this problem before, but have forgotten how to fix it.
Though, with crontab -e, it's five time fields followed by the command to run. in /etc/crontab, it's 5 time fields, followed by username, followed by the command to run.
Your initial paste didn't have the 0 ...
Thanks, but I can't seem to get it to work properly. I suppose I'll look online further.
crontab -e (WITHOUT sudo) -> 0 5 * * * rm -rf ~/.Trash/*
Oh wait, that's the old location. In newer releases, it's ~/.local/share/Trash/*
Yeah, I was about to say, haha.
I don't understand. Crontab -e -> 0 5 * * * rm -rf ~/.local/share/Trash/* -> Still not working
How do you determine that it does not work?
I have the gnome schedule and I tested it there. Perhaps I'll just set it to 1 minute and see the results. Thanks for everything, but I have to go. Bye :)
Sure, you can use gnome-schedule instead of crontab -e
